not my idea, it’s from reading amitav ghosh in class

my latest (likely brief) big idea fixation is that reality represented in fiction becomes less real. a sense of realism in fiction is generally based on expectations of how a story or genre should play out, rather than physical probability or what is possible
this obviously isn’t something nonary games specific tho. I’d call this the poetics of conspiracy if I was trying to publish an article or pitch some pop psychology to nymag or whatever
@NARFNra oh yeah I do that about anything of course. but I do thematic infodumping too!! I’m a versatile npc
a sense that a status quo makes its own atrocities seem like conspiracy theories

this analogy is maybe stretched a little just to say that I feel like a character from VLR all the time. I’ll tell people why forces are evil in a long digression that seems unrelated and the immediately be complicit in that force because of a lack of choice

vlr is particularly funny because most of the characters know why things are happening and will overshare with sigma, but he rarely understands why he’s being told about stuff outside the game, and everyone is forced in some way or another into being self-interested

the estranged parallel in 999 is where characters go on and on about the socio-political fuck ups of a random pharmaceutical company in a way that is both distant and responsible for the events in the game. but knowing and sharing the conspiracy averts nothing

“the nixon administration flooded poor areas with crack and fabricated the war on drugs” is one of infinite evils that should explain the falseness of american cultural attitudes. but it doesn’t, not really, in the sense that speaking about this has no definite result

when I go on these digressions it’s as if I’m foreshadowing something terrible or exposed some logic that the world revolves around—but of course nothing happens. or I’ll even meet a spectrum of disbelief, the mention of atrocity can’t really be matched with proportionate action
the connection is what seems like or sounds like conspiracy, but also, and first, it’s the immediate effect of the conspiratorial mode of speaking

often enough I’ll be in situations where I find reason enough, but also no reason at all, to say stuff like “have you heard about mkultra” “did you know the fbi would gangstalk and impersonate non-white activists” “ford used to hire militias to kill striking employees”

I used to think the way the nonary games series would stop everything for “hey have you heard of this incomprehensible theory” was silly but in retrospect it’s out of place because it’s too specific to life

you have to give people from their context the ability and space to present and interpret that context. cultural difference is obvious, artistic traditions are also traceable, but they’re dynamic interactions that take place on a huge fucking constellation of life

the racism against japanese (and other foreign games) was incredibly bad in the 00s, but saying japan makes more special or true art is an embarrassing overcorrective. (though at this point I’m not sure people coming into games would know about stuff that went down in the 00s)

because the shift I care about is arts productions that come out of and serve localized contexts, that are embedded in actual care and microhistories. I do not care if art that comes out of this practice is ugly, in fact, I would prefer it

or really what I want to say is that there's nothing wrong with ugly, garish, pathetic, and stupid art, I'm really fond of the artistic output of artistic failure. to me it's kind of useless and stressful to attribute these qualities overwhelmingly toward your political opponents
anyway it's a totally belligerent and probably nostalgic argument to think that just by having higher standards for art production, capital will meet those standards

nfts are fucked up because they add wasteful bloat to what is just a database and through that waste are trying to make provenance something that's hot, corporate, and mainstream, instead of something that rich british failsons argue about

there is a real sense of fighting fire with fire to be like, no! hypocrite that you are! you do not have the randian claim to creativity and innovation that you think you have! like is that the line we want to draw in the sand?

nfts are technically proficient first and are formally creative second. I'm not claiming that personally and I don't believe that, but those values are the smokescreen they use to justify their romantic evolutionary struggle to exist.

broadly usa is really, really stuck in this discourse mode that art needs to be beautiful, technically proficient, and/or creative. this is really funny in an usian context because, well, look around at our popular culture

this isn't really a big deal, but, people love pointing out how nfts are "ugly" or "bad art." and they are, but similar to the "asset-flip" dogwhistle, this language comes with an assortment of implications that are enmeshed with the ascendancy of nfts

what’s unique is that music is, like, really old, arguably emergent along human sociality, and this observation remains pretty solid through its history. professionalization wouldn’t always be the right lens but the social limits are generally constant

this is only sort of generally true and especially more about a history of popular music, but, there is way less room to perform being a “traitor” in music. you need the right gear, right production, right studio, and the right sound

in music this is super structural and immediate. by sounding like everyone else and/or how you’re expected to sound, you’re “in,” and this is why career musicians have to take input from extremely boring consensus and producers and etc
this is “selling out” but with less magic emphasis put on the transaction. it’s not compensation that makes boring art, but social identification with bourgeois worries, mores, anxieties

professionalization in music is something that feels really easy to conceptualize but hard for me to talk about. it typically results in boring music because a professional musician is expected to conform, rather than (perform) non-conformity

stormcrowfleet is one of a scant few “metal” albums that are like circumstantially metal, because it was and is a new kind of music, something that leveraged metal’s impoverished obscurity but none of its traditions

and unlike a lot of minimalist music it is cloyingly, romantically beautiful. so altogether, the sound is like a transposition of naive beauty into a strange and impossible surrounding, opposing ideas effortlessly synthesized by just not caring about how things are supposed to be

skepticism’s later material starts to feel like contemporary classical played with metal instruments, but stormcrowfleet is undermined by its cheapness and cacophony. yet it never feels like it’s trying to be abrasive or weird on purpose—it’s like it’s outside purpose itself
“modern classical” such as minimalism resists being listened to but actually accelerates interpretation, as steady, studied breaks in form invite comparison

the minimalist, drone-like, microtonal songwriting crawls and is hard to grasp, though I think difficulty identifying changes is a commonality of slow music. stormcrowfleet’s conservatory aspirations are drowned by a cheapness: cheesy synths, muddy tone, absolutely no mixing

skepticism’s stormcrowfleet sounds like nothing else in the world. it achieves an ambient register through mixing and sound but has the activity and abrasive ness of death(doom) metal. crucial to this is the brush drumming, which conveys words like fragile, lush, overwhelming

@NARFNra anyway, I’m going to bed, sorry for being a nerd in your mentions. the monologue thing was one of the main things I liked from the essay despite the confusing way its written so I wanted to talk about it

@NARFNra what gets me about LND is like, when something doesn’t hold up to a certain reading or lens (e.g. bioshock fails to critique or embody objectivism) identfying that is just doing criticism, the LND layer on top tries to make specific readings universal and it falls apart

@NARFNra LND is a can of worms lol. I keep thinking about it from different directions, but probably, LND looks at a game as an argument first. then yeah if the game is logically sound then it gets to be a monologue (…or maybe an essay)
@NARFNra …while vgs often get turned into logical systems or arguments and are not given that same room

@NARFNra yeah. the one sticking point with using monologue as the frame of reference (though not mentioned in the essay) is that people [academics] have tons of patience and grace for literature that’s self-contradictory or meant to be read within a whole context…

@NARFNra I look at games with choices as basically being in superposition so I favor interpreting it like a monologue, though undertale’s writing definitely isn’t “shaped” like a monologue because it’s so reactive

@NARFNra the monologue comparison is probably only useful in this context of replying to other ppl’s critiques though because videogames are more like… idk thick contexts, they are literary but not entirely and literary comparisons fit only awkwardly
@NARFNra the literary frame is sound though. an actual monologue cannot contradict its monologue-ness without ceasing to be a monologue (as alone it can contradict its content but not its form)

@NARFNra “contradiction as endpoint” is probably a negation, something that causes the monologue to cease being a monologue—which according to this framework is only possible if you assume the game isn’t a monologue. hmm… it’s circular logic lol
@NARFNra seemingly this is a metaphysical argument about non-real forms, I guess, which is a different kind of contradiction

@NARFNra a monologue as a literary device is only itself. it can contain contradictions but it can’t contradict itself—so anything that appears to be a contradiction is in fact a modulation (monologues are not “real” after all)

@NARFNra Is your brother like an evil scientist from an old timey cartoon

like comic books, videogames never has a period of community independence and never got lucky enough for one to spontaneously be created (like whatever happened with film). unlike comic books, amazon, google, and apple fucking need videogames and are scrambling to monopolize them

a corollary is the lack of a critical mass of people saying “fuck your approval,” types of mass movements that are easy to remember for other mediums. that’s both the depth of this memetic grudge and the unique condition of videogames as being dreamed up as accessories to power
you can see the grudge it in how extreme the supporters and detractors of vgs still are. it’s always all or nothing, in a way that’s semantically unique compared to other media I think…

videogames historically descend from institutional power and have always had the ties to buy into it. facing the scarcity of burgeoning late capitalism, their exclusion was justified by an aesthetic lack. and that cultural memetic grudge persists into the current day

videogames are maybe pathologically unable to conceive of a counter culture because its primordial vision of success is 1. becoming rich 2. becoming culturally powerful 3. becoming something everyone can/should play
second this dynamic is not a main driver anymore but it undergirds how people seek approval and what they do to achieve it

first, in fairness, there always was and still kind of is a hyperbolic dismissal of videogames. one of my new favorite pieces of trivia is that joseph brodsky disowned his son for caring more about videogames than poetry

this is an undeveloped historical vg theory, but I think we’re in the long tail decimation of people desperately wanting games to have mainstream approval. similar to the nerd identity contradiction, a retained underdog internalization that doesn’t match up to reality

nintendo wouldn’t be able to match this for two more years, not until mario 3

that is to say alex kidd is like an arcade game without a time limit... that sounds simplistic but there’s a lot of care put into each screen and you have the time and space given to appreciate that texture

sega’s arcade development had a lot of crossover with its home console development (especially sg-1000 days) and the relationship was much more mutualistic. analogous to atari, sega would adapt or even better bore deeper into the arcade games they already were known for

thinking holistically nintendo was trying to break away from the arcade while inevitably also borrowing heavily from it, you can feel this gradual progression through the first two or three years of famicom games
8-bit sega is better than the era’s tendency for arcade conversions (including sega’s 8-bit arcade conversations) because they translate arcade language and conventions into a tighter container

Academia annoys me because people purposefully or naively mix up occupational anxiety with something more existential and important to life. I’m patient when it comes to people’s material worries but it is frustrating to constantly come in contact with this secular false piety

A critic does imagine what could be possible in the present and future. We all learn by proximity to each other’s imagination. I’m losing the plot here and sounding idiotic because criticism can only be read and reflected on; nonfiction can never author a conclusion

I have often got a critique of my methodology that is like: “Just saying no thank you oppression doesn’t defeat it,” and that is right. From opposite directions my detractors and I agree that critics do not change things through criticism (and that is not really the point of it)
Fuck a gig economy, fuck labor precarity, and fuck respectability

The way art and writing continues this myth of needing institutional legitimacy puts the minority of participants (ppl with visible, high profile jobs) in an unfair position and closes the imagination on how any of us can be participating
Art criticism is a search for problems and theoretical solutions. I resent the narrative that it’s some elevated thing that needs special protection. Everyone has that capacity for creativity

@NARFNra https://t.co/mEckCKCKYB this is one of my favorites, it’s technically an unfinished demo but it feels finished to me

it's a really unique take on the one big fuck dungeon genre that still feels like it has character building, rather than being rng dependent. unfortunately people probably need at least dumbass rpg kanji literacy to play it since there's a billion different stats

it's pretty immaculately balanced though so each ten floors or so feels like a new "expansion" with new monsters that throw a wrench in your strategy, and new kinds(!) of items. the game mostly avoids straight upgrades and encourages character branching

this is where the kind of annoying accumulation aspects come in, because 1. you can get your old equipment back if you can make it back where you died without dying again and 2. you don't lose your currencies on death

so when it comes to building your character there's a labyrinth of choices that far reaching consequences for circumstances you can't predict, because you can only go so far at any time (or risk dying and losing everything equipped)

there's a lot of equipment in the game since there's no "play" besides equip and pray... and every single item can be fused into another item, though it starts becoming prohibitively expensive. sort of like smt fusion w/ items (but actually more complicated)

so it's an auto combat roguelike, wait come back.

so it's an auto combat roguelike, which is probably the worst two modern permutations of videogame rpg. yet, brought together they make a puzzle game. the rpg protagonist is a solution set to throw at the dungeon

at this point when someone poses with "where are all the non-violent games?" they're just trying to sell theirs

@farawaythyer though I'm not familiar with the dev's work, there's also the issue of like, one game getting ascribed all the credit of something that was definitely mutualistically realized (when usually it didn't even want or was trying to monopolize that credit anyway)

instead of a diversity of approach, or like, really addressing all the different kinds of games (even the stupid ones, even the seemingly worthless ones), we have a mode of like "splatoon is truly a subversive non-violent game" when it's still fundamentally an online shooter

so maybe yume nikki is not thought of as a triumph of "non-violent" gaming because it's "about" existing in a space, without any gamey goals ppl grew up with... fundamental assumptions like that filter out games and art that already do exist

considering stuff that is, or is adjacent to, simulation, which makes up a huge swath of historically non-violent (though possibly competitive) games reveals how much of this is market sycophancy, or anyway very top down aesthetic demands stemming from the role of AAA games

you can observe this unwholesomeness throughout other categories too, like student games, "tool assisted game development" (mods, rpgmaker, etc), art projects, "asset flips;" the various convergence of hobbyist game practices that don't really intersect with games store front

@SylvanFlux I've never been that good at communicating on twitter, sorry for the misunderstanding. a very popular position people have is that if managers did a good job, no one would ever crunch. 

which I think is wishful thinking and ppl should have a contingency for when they don't!
the fact that "people just need to manage projects better" is a more popular position than "games should be cheaper to make" just fucking blows me away

games as service gimmicks & 100 hour campaigns require herculean amounts of labor and devtime. especially to stay competitive

the longer a project goes on for, the likelihood for mistakes and mismanagement increases. regardless of genius!
